barrel_cortex package¶

Module contents¶

Initialisation file for the barrel_cortex module

This module should contain everything that’s related to the entire barrel cortex. It includes:

  • average_barrel_field_L45_border.am: barrel cortex geometry, to be rendered in AMIRA

  • barrel_cortex.py: contains functions specific to barrel cortex simulations, such as synaptic strength readout, methods to move morphologies in barrel cortex…

Date: 10/01/2023

barrel_cortex.calculate_point_distance(p1, p2)[source]¶
barrel_cortex.construct_pt3add(values)[source]¶
barrel_cortex.convertible_to_float(x)[source]¶
barrel_cortex.correct_hoc_depth(hoc_in, hoc_reference_or_depth, coordinate_system_z_move='C2', measure_fun=functools.partial(<function get_distance_below_L45_barrel_surface>, barrel='C2'), outpath=None)[source]¶

Variables: reference_depth_or_hoc: depth in which to put morphology, either specified through float or

a path to a hoc morphology from which the soma centroid position will be extracted and used as depth

coordinate_system_z_move: which z axis to choose to move the morphology.

Must be one of the barrels (‘C1’, ‘Alpha’, …)

measure_fun: function that receives a point and returns a depth. Typical choices:

partial(get_distance_below_L45_barrel_surface, barrel = ‘C2’) get_distance_below_L45_surface

barrel_cortex.get_z_coordinate_necessary_to_put_point_in_specified_depth(p, depth, coordinate_system_z_move='C2', measure_fun=functools.partial(<function get_distance_below_L45_barrel_surface>, barrel='C2'))[source]¶
barrel_cortex.move_hoc_absolute(hocpath, x, y, z, outpath=None)[source]¶

moves hoc morphology such that soma centroid is at absolute position x,y,z. The coordinates must be in the global coordinate system, i.e. D2

barrel_cortex.move_hoc_to_hoc(hoc_in, hoc_reference, outpath=None)[source]¶
barrel_cortex.move_hoc_xyz(hocpath, x, y, z, outpath=None, coordinate_system='D2')[source]¶

moves hoc morphology in xyz directions in the coordinate system of the specified barrel. Cave: The coordinate system might be different from Roberts definition of local coordinate systems. It is generated as follows: - z is the local z axis of the column - x has the same orientation as in the global coordinate system, but is tilted in its z component to be orthogonal on the locaal z axis. - y is orthogonal to both, roughly pointing in the y direction of the global coordinate system
